Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2007 04:40PM lc111350 wrote: Hi Wendy, I had stage 1 grade 2 er/pr pos her2 neg. I also was not expecting the rec for chemo but I checked out the MD Anderson web site and looked at their protocol. Friday I finished 4 rounds of cytoxan/epirubicin. We did dose dense (every 2 weeks) b/c I could shave a month off my treatment. I'm glad it's over. I did pretty good, continued to work, was very tired, took good drugs for nausea and diarrhea. Get that oncotype dx done and get another oncologist. and check out MD Anderson's website and see where you fit in their treatment protocol. best of luck to you, be strong, Lexapro is a great antidepressant and you might ask about it.
Posts.Title: Should I take chemo? WendyInCalif WendyInCalif

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2007 09:52PM lc111350 wrote: I've had 18 treatments now and have developed a burn bad enough that I didn't get my treatment yesterday, they told me to come back Thursday to see if my skin is enough better to resume tx. My rad onc said using lotions, etc won't prevent skin damage but will help once it starts. Since I saw the first sign of pink I've been using radiaguard with aloe, I've been wearing mostly cotton bras, and airing out when I get home. Yesterday they gave me aquaphor to use also. It feels a little better today than yesterday so hopefully I can get started back on Thursday. I hate to drag this out longer than I have to.
Posts.Title: June 07 Rads leebrigs Lynn12

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2007 10:10PM lc111350 wrote: I've had 18 treatments and have been put on hold for a pretty bad burn primarily under my breast, but I've read lots of posts where women had no burn at all. Watch out for week 3-4, they told me that's when you're more likely to get a burn if you're going to. Don't hesitate to call attention to it even if it's not your day to see the doctor. I've had some mild fatigue but nothing like I had with the chemo. The burn is looking better so hopefully I'll get back on track by Friday. Except for having to string this out longer I have enjoyed being able to skip the daily treatments this week.
Posts.Title: June 07 Rads leebrigs Lynn12

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2007 09:33PM lc111350 wrote: 2 weeks down as of today! It really is flying by. I'm getting treatments during lunch hour now instead of end of my work day and am so glad to be getting back home at my usual time. They gave me a lotion to use that I will pass on. It is Radia-Guard Radiation Treatment Lotion and is very soothing, is OTC so no script needed. Don't get the cream as it has alcohol in it and will dry the skin. They even said I could use it in the mornings as long as it was at least 4 hours before the treatment. I hope all my sisters are cruising through this relatively well.
Posts.Title: June 07 Rads leebrigs Lynn12

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2007 09:30PM lc111350 wrote: SNJulie, I would like to know more about the Canadian protocol. It sure would be nice to be done early. Are the doses the same as US? Recurrence rates comparable? The least amount necessary sure seems to make sense. I also have fairly large breasts. They told me to get a 100%cotton bra (inmpossible to find)so I am wearing a tank type T shirt under my mostly cotton bra at work and just the T or nothing at home. It seems to be a lot more comfortable. Skin on skin seems to be a big part of the problem and I need a "lift" to get the breast off the chest wall.
Posts.Title: June 07 Rads leebrigs Lynn12

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2007 03:09AM lc111350 wrote: thanks Julie and Kathy for the info. I have also had the 40lb boob syndrome but it gets better a few hours after treatment, and since I've been on hold this week b/c of the burn it's feeling a lot better. also get shooting pains out the nipple sometimes...anyway, I'll just be glad when it's all over with as we all will. I'll see the doc tomorrow. My kids are coming this weekend to go out on the boat and I'm unsure about what kind of sunscreen to use or even if I should go out with them. I don't want to miss out on the fun and I'd like to take a dip in the lake to cool off. Any suggestions?
Posts.Title: June 07 Rads leebrigs Lynn12

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2007 10:02PM lc111350 wrote: hey there sisters, hope everyone had a good weekend. As far as the swimming and boating Julie, my doc told me just to put on a lot of sunscreen and keep my area covered. ok to swim, etc. It was sure nice to do something "normal". I have not had any problems with my arm but since my nodes were neg they're not zapping the axilla. I think you might expect some problems if they were. I also seem to be a little on the hypervigilent side of watching for any side effects.

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2007 08:01AM lc111350 wrote: I am seriously considering stopping the rads. I had to take almost a week off because of my skin, went back and had 3 treatments and stopped again. I've had a total of 21 treatments now. I've already lost about a third of my left breast volume and I'm wondering how there could be any cancer left there. I had a very small tumor(just over 1cm) and did 4AC and thought this would be cake compared to the chemo. I'm going to take arimidex also (ER/PR pos, HER2 neg). Does anyone know if they have looked at local recurrence in women who have stopped treatment early? My rad onc said the original studies they used to pick the total dose were on head and neck tumors and they just extrapolated the results to breast cancer. :-( I've tried to be positive through this whole thing, worked every day even through the chemo, but I am feeling like I've just had enough.
Posts.Title: June 07 Rads leebrigs Lynn12

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2007 10:27PM lc111350 wrote: hey there to all my rad sisters, I'm down 15 treatments now, I've got some mild redness and after yesterday's treatment my breast felt like it weighed about 40 lbs but that went away. the only fatigue I've had is because I let my sweet husband talk me into going out on a week night to listen to some great live music until after midnight and had to get up early the next morning and go to work. I guess I'm too old to party on a week night! :-) the lotion they gave me is very soothing and I am using it three times a day. Everybody hang in there, it sounds like we're all cruising pretty well through this.
Posts.Title: June 07 Rads leebrigs Lynn12

Posts.Content: May 2, 2007 03:46PM lc111350 wrote: Hi Anne, it was based on tumor size. They have recently lowered the limit on size and I fell in to their new recommendations. I asked the radiation onc what he would do if it was his wife and there was no hesitation about doing it. I also saw my mother die from metastatic breast cancer and I felt like I had to do everything I could. Lastly I had a rare skin rash that is associated with malignancy that got worse after the lumpectomy and I figured my body was talking to me and I should listen.
Posts.Title: Should I take chemo? WendyInCalif WendyInCalif

Posts.Content: May 30, 2007 09:52AM lc111350 wrote: I'm jumping in too. I get my first rad today during my lunch hour. I feel more anxious than I expected. I finished my chemo a month ago and my energy is better but not my old self yet. I have all the same concerns that have been mentioned but I am hoping for the best. I figure if I can work everyday through the chemo I can do this. As far as tamoxifen, if you are post menopausal they recommend arimidex or femara...less side effects for us older gals.

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2007 12:08PM lc111350 wrote: I saw the rad onc yesterday and we decided to do the boosts and give the rest of the breast a rest then finish with the last 6 whole breast treatments. It all looks much better after a week of no treatments so I'm hoping this strategy works. Thanks so much to all of you for all the support and encouragement. Susan, the gray area is going to peel, or that's what mine did under the breast and now there is nice fresh skin there again.
